ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: lots of calculus ideas like: Riemann sums, integrals, convergence/divergence, polar coordinates, arc length, etc.

I had already taken BC Calculus before taking this course, so I learned different ways to approach calculus concepts. I was also able to solidify some of the concepts that I hadn't fully understood when I took the course the first time.
Integration, Riemann sums, convergence and divergence, parametric equations, polar coordinates.
Calculus 2. Good understanding of the concepts.

I developed the ability to measure the area under curves, understanding of converging and diverging series, calculate the volume of objects, and several other things. I think this course sharpened my critical thinking and abstract thinking (I found series pretty abstract).
Calculus, Matherical methods which will certainly be useful in economics
Calculus

I had already taken Calculus BC in high school but knew I wanted to take Calc II again because I had taken the class during COVID when teaching was poor. For that reason, I especially appreciated Brett's clarity in lectures and picture-perfect black-board drawings that aided in my understanding of every topic. I now feel much more confident in Calc II topics.
I further developed my ability to reason my way through complex problems.

I learned how to approach mathematics from a new perspective, as it required me to think beyond just learning the material. Most the exam consisted in applying these concepts in a way that you could only do if you actually understood the material.
I learned the foundations behind Calc ii including integration strategies, volumes of Revolution, series, and para metrics. There was a special focus on the fundamental math behind these concepts.
It strengthened my logical problem solving skills.
Improved on skills learned in Math 112 and learned more advanced calculus, including improper integrals and series.
I learned calculus.
I learned about advanced methods for finding the anti derivatives of functions, volumes of polar and cartesian curves, series, etc.
I learned how to take integrals, evaluate convergence of series, and briefly touched upon applications of integrals, parametric equations, and polar expressions of area.
Insights into how calculus can be used to tackle real world problems
Learned all about Calc 2
This class is a good follow-up to AP Calculus AB, students who took AP Calculus BC will be well prepared as the topics covered in that course will be similar to this one.
I developed my collaboration, self-advocacy, and self-evaluation skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths - lots of partner work which was helpful (especially when I was lost). really liked how we talked about the big ideas and what questions we would be answering today, as that kept everything in perspective

weaknesses - class could move incredibly fast and leave students with little time to take notes and actually engage in the material. I had already learned some of the material in high school, and some of the explanations in this class left me confused (would've had a hard time if it weren't for my previous knowledge).

Strengths: good amount of content, pacing 
Weaknesses: classes and professors teach a lot of the theory, but provide very little instruction in how to actually solve problems like students are then assigned

I really liked the "explorations" that we had to do for homework. They were an effective way to introduce us to/get us thinking about the concepts we were going to discuss in class the next day and very time efficient. I also like that my teacher held his office hours on Monday-Wednesday, front-loading the week since the problem sets were due on Wednesday. I really liked that we had a chance to do some practice problems (or even just "polls") in class before having to do the problems on our own.
I loved the Maths Stories.

I enjoyed the way of teaching. (Every new topic came with an exploration of the new idea before it was explained in class). I would have enjoyed some more guidance on practicing outside of the weekly problem sets.

I thought the course material was very well organized. It was always evident to me what we were learning about and how it tied into a previous piece of material. A huge strength of this course is that practice exams and exam review sessions are offered. If you're a student reading this take advantage of those! One weakness I found was that some ULA's were not as willing to help during office hours. One ULA in particular would work on their own homework while they're supposed to be helping other students and I found that frustrating.
Brett is a great instructor and he made classes very engaging.

I liked how consistent the problem sets were in their difficulty and length, and how approachable Brett was with any questions we had, especially during his many office hours. However, I have heard that Brett is by far the best professor for MATH115 and don't know how much my experience would have been affected by having a different professor, so I wish there was more consistency in the teaching.

A strength is the way that the assignments are set up. Before each class, there are brief homework assignments that introduce students to the material that will be presented the next day. The midterms were also well spaced. One weakness of the course is that the problem sets were due Wednesday night, when we would cover the material needed to complete problems Wednesday morning in class. This meant that it was challenging to get ahead on the psets, as I didnt yet understand the material.

This course moved at a good pace  but the weakness was that the PSETs were way more difficult than the material learned in class. Sometimes, the notes were not help enough, which would force to learn the material through other resources.

Strength: I was able to learn WHY the concepts worked as they did. We learned the background of these complex topics. 

Weakness: I wish we did more examples in class together.
There was a lot of variance in what the different sections' teachers taught, especially in the convergence tests unit.
Strengths: the Professor is probably one of the most gifted teachers Ive ever seen, and my high school teachers were good teachers.

Strength: there is so much help available whether by peer tutoring or office hours. 
Weakness: the lecture style was not as structured as it could have been. Much of my notes were useless when it came to figuring out how to do the homework. Id recommend guided notes/examples that explicitly show how a problem should be done to completion.

The strengths of the course are the array of resources available to students seeking extra support (there are many hours of peer tutoring and office hours available). The weaknesses of the course are that I believe it requires a significant amount of background knowledge of Calculus 2 in order to keep up with the pace of the work.
The course structure was really good. Builds nicely from integration to series then into applications which was good.
It's math, if you don't like math, don't take it. If you do like math, it's pretty fun. Esp if you have Brett.

Strengths: There were a lot of resources provided in this class, including a great network of peer tutors and extended office hours. There is also a lot of review sessions provided before exams that were extremely helpful. 
Weaknesses: a lot of the material was difficult and extensive: need to be prepared for extensive work on problem sets and review of class material.
Print out the notes ahead of time for Brett's section.
The strengths is that the course offers aid to the students with many peer tutoring hours but the weakness is that it is very fast paced so it can be easy to become very lost in the class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: With Brett, this was a good class. He is very patient, always willing to reexplain concepts when asked, and an understanding professor. Most people aren't out here talking calc just for the heck of it, if you need to take 115 and are dreading it, I recommend trying for Brett's section, as it'll probably make your life a whole lot easier
yes but I would warn them to be honest about their interest in math and prior experience. I would not recommend this class to someone who was not entirely confident in their abilities.
Unless you really like math or need it as a prereq I would not take this course
I would only recommend the course if the student likes Math and already has some experience with BC calc. I don't think they'd enjoy the class that much if either of those weren't true for them.
Depends, if it is required for their major or future classes they want to take. I would definitely recommend reading the textbook. It can also be satisfying at times.
I would recommend taking the course, especially if you have not done much calculus and even if you are not going to use it. I think It improves your thinking.

I would recommend it if you have an interest in continuing the calculus sequence. The material around series was very difficult for me to grasp but I really enjoyed the first third and the last third of the course. I found the material substantially more difficult than Calculus I so be prepared to work hard if you enroll.
Yes, because it is an interesting course which is also required for many majors
Yes, I definitely learnt a lot about calculus concepts. This is a great foundational course.

Yes, if you want to get a solid background knowledge of calculus to apply to any number of STEM-related fields. It's also a prereq for many other classes so you may be required to take it. If you do, try to get in Brett's section.
Yes, I completely recommend this course to another student as it is very well organized and engaging.
I would highly recommend this course with Brett as the professor.
Yes
Yes. The material was straightforward and the instructors were all really helpful.
If you're taking this course it's probably a prerequisite, so take it if you have to. It's not as bad of a prerequisite as other courses.
Yes. If you get Professor Brett Smith, you will learn very well because he structures his lessons in a way that helps you really understand the material.
Yes, calculus is a really fun type of math thats useful for higher levels of math and engineering.
I would recommend this course to students who have a strong math background and are able to keep up with the fast-paced Calculus 2 content.
Yea, builds a good understanding of calculus which will be very useful in many majors
Yes, if you like math.
I would recommend this course: it is an important prerequisite and covers a wide variety of mathematical topics.
Take this if you have a strong background. Calc AB was not sufficient for me.
I would recommend this course to another student. The level of difficulty is a bit high, but the peer tutoring and office hours are extremely useful.
